div1.p: Carter writes about when anti-breeding methods can be safely stopped.

div1.head: Memorandum from Henry Rose Carter, [n.d.]
div1.p:
Two problems, short; easy, and it may be of considerable practical
importance are

(x) For each bench man in the locality in which he happens to be in
the late fall, to determine the last date at which Anopheles mosquitoes
(quads. especially) infective to men can be found in nature.

(y) Of scarcely less value is it to determine the date at which the
flight of the spring brood of quads. begins.

The value of (x) is to determine when we can safely stop anti-breeding
methods at any p lace. Thus, Mayne determined that Anopheles infective to
men were not found after--say--Nov. 15th. at Monroe, La. (I have forgotten the
exact date.)

Now the mosquito infective on Nov. 15th. must have received infection
on or prior to November 4th. The egg from which she has evolved must have
been deposited not less than 17 days before she fed (16 days from egg to
image + 1 day for probosis to harden). Very obviously then, we could
afford to stop antilarval methods on that day, as eggs deposited after
October 12th would not produce i mages that would infect this year. In point
of fact, this allows for a large factor of safety, because in the interval
from Nov. 4th. to Nov. 15th. (at which date it is cold enough for the para-
site to die in the mosquito) we may be quite certain it is too cold to
allow only 11 days for its development in the mosquito (extrinsic incubation
of malaria). It would take--say-- 25 to 30 days. (It takes 11 days in
Panama.)

Similarly, between October 12th. and November 4th. the weather is too
cold to allow only 16 days for the cycle from egg to imago (I have allowed
only one day for the hardening of the chitin so that the insect can feed on
man)/

I had in 1918--it is now either in the Central Office or Mayne has
it--a chart from the Agricultural Department. I have forgotten its
name, but it could well be called “A Chart of Iso-biological Phenomena
Dates”, in which the curves show the places in the U. S. where certain
biological phenomena, such as I have just instanced, occur on the same
dates.

Guided by this, and allowing a fair factor of safety, in 1918 I
stopped my anti-larval work on dates (different, of course) thus deter-
mined from Camp Meade, Md. to Houston, although Anopheles were then in
flight and breeding. There was some argument about it, but I knew it
was right and I think I sa ved at least $150,000.00 and, taking the fac-
tors of safety, I did with absolute safety.

In our records we have several determinations of the date of this
termination of infectivity, but a considerable number of others are
needed to serve as checks on the above map when used for control of mos-
quito production.

It is very little trouble to make this determination and I know
you can see how useful it may be in preventing unnecessary field work.

(y) is advisable for the control of malaria on impounded water.
A. quad. bred in the ponds is, we think, the main factor in the production
of malaria from impounded water. (I will have rather an interesting
little piece to add to this, when I am able to sit up and write, on the
role of punctipennis). Now our accepted--and a very efficient--method
of preventing p roduction i n the large ponds is by holding the pond as
high as possible during the season when quads. are not in flight (i.e.
being produced) lowering it before this flight begins, but as close to
the time as may be. A pond thus handled (as is the case here now)
having an absolutely clean shore line and decently stocked with top-minnows
gives no production.

You can see then how advisable it is to hold the high water level as
close to the first flight as possible, but on no account to go into it.
We have in our Service literature, and a few notes of my own, these dates
for 25 or 30 different places and years. Thibault, of Scott, Arkansas,
gave me some data on it, and everything he reports can be relied on.
One would have to fish it out from Service publications and reports, but
this is not hard to do and it gives us data which I judge will prevent
from 5,000 to 10,000 cases of malaria per annum by the ponds, and to do
this is worth some days work. Barber, as I recalled, gave the data this
Spring of the first flight of A. quad. at either Crowley or Camilla.
